discussion.content: I thought the answer is A because with STP it can prevent switching loops as the question says 'the supervisor wants vlan 100 to be the management subnet and ALL SWITCHES to share the VLAN information'. So while sharing information to ALL SWITCHES it could create a loop. sUggest me for this question..

Side note: 

With regard to VTP as a technology there are many a network engineer who have reservations (personal opinion mind you) on its implementation. Briefly, it's highly recommended (if at all used) to manually disable VTP after convergence of the configuration throughout the targeted switches. 

As a matter, I have heard and read that most network engineers (due the potential catastrophe that misconfigured switches can have on the network) prefer to opt for manual configuration and document accordingly. 

But as said before it's a personal opinion, and let the various forums of discussion on the topic let you decide (an example listed below)...

Stay away from VTP?
https://community.cisco.com/t5/switching/stay-away-from-vtp/td-p/2462234

As VTP (VLAN Trunking) is a Cisco propriety technology, as a network admin he/she would need to be 100% confident that ALL affected switches are from the Cisco brand.

...also if VTP is part of the solution, then the question should have stipulated that all switches are Cisco. But it a moot topic of discussion as all possible answers have VTP mentioned as part of the solution. 

Safe bet to opt (like 802.1Q) for open source as this would mitigate any problems with future deployments (if documentation of network layout was not up to scratch - e.g. a new hire, unaware of the network layout / configuration installs a non-Cisco switch).

Ergo:

'IEEE 802.1ak defines a protocol called Multiple VLAN Registration Protocol or MVRP in short. '

Source:

https://superuser.com/questions/692188/instead-of-vtp-what-protocol-can-be-used-for-non-cisco-switches

questions.question_text:
A technician is being tasked to centralize the management of the switches and segment the switches by broadcast domains. The company is currently all on
VLAN1 using a single private IP address range with a 24 bit mask. The supervisor wants VLAN 100 to be the management subnet and all switches to share the
VLAN information.
Which of the following options would work BEST to accomplish these requirements?

choices.B: Use VLSM on the IP address range with VTP and 802.1x on all inter switch connections with native VLAN 100
choices.D: Use VLSM on the IP address range with VTP and 802.1q on the inter switch connections with native VLAN 100
choices.C: Use VLSM on VLAN1, with VTP and 802.1w on the inter switch connections with native VLAN 100
choices.A: Use VLSM on the IP address range, with STP and 802.1q on the inter switch connections with native VLAN 100

discussion.content: what are the two commands to type in the switch?

questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP -
Wireless network users recently began experiencing speed and performance issues after access point 2 (AP2) was replaced due to faulty hardware. The original network was installed according to a consultant's specifications and has always worked without a problem.
You a network technician, have been tasked with evaluating the situation and resolving the issues to improve both performance and connectivity. Refer to the following exhibits and perform any necessary changes to the wireless and wired infrastructure by adjusting devices. Note: Adjust the LEAST number of devices needed to fix the issue.
Select and Place:
//IMG//
questions.answer_description: After you fix AP2, you must click on the switch, which will bring up the switch interface. Type in the two commands that they show there, to prove the fix. Do not worry that interface 4 is down, there is no interface 4 for you to do.

questions.question_text:
A company suffers an outage due to a bad module in a core switch.
Which of the following is the proper order of troubleshooting?

choices.C: Establish a theory, identify the problem, duplicate the problem, test the theory, and repeat.
choices.A: Gather information, start at the top of the OSI model, and work down.
choices.B: Establish a plan of action to solve the problem.
choices.D: Gather information, start at the bottom of the OSI model, and work up.

discussion.content: I agree D should be the correct answer
I thinks D is correct answer

questions.question_text:
Two switches are connected using both a CAT6 cable and a CAT5e cable.
Which of the following problems is occurring?

discussion.content:
Not sure what cable types have to do with the problem description. Anyhow, taking all the answers in to account, the probable correct answer (through extrapolation) is indeed D, but only surmised through a process of elimination. 

Not sure if this level of exam complexity (trick questions) is within the scope of a COMPTIA Network + exam...

I'll let the link below do the rest of the talking:

https://superuser.com/questions/1353090/can-using-cat-6-and-5e-cause-a-switching-loop

choices.B: Reset the statistics counter for this interface
choices.C: Remove default 802.1q tag and set to server VLAN
choices.A: Shutdown and then re-enable this interface

discussion.content:
moreover, C is correcgt, but whilst I'm here:

'What VLAN 1?

VLAN Design Guidelines (3.3.2.1) Cisco switches have a factory configuration in which default VLANs are preconfigured to support various media and protocol types. The default Ethernet VLAN is VLAN 1. It is a security best practice to configure all the ports on all switches to be associated with VLANs other than VLAN 1'

http://www.ciscopress.com/articles/article.asp?p=2181837&seqNum=11

Side note: VTP (VLAN Trunking Protocol) configured networks may need to be manually re-verified; possible rule of thumb due to its autoconfiguration nature to propagate settings or configurations throughout the local network. 

Food for thought:
https://community.cisco.com/t5/switching/stay-away-from-vtp/td-p/2462234

what is Mbs? is it Mbps or MB/s? Not sure Mbs is an accepted syntax for data throughput measurement. A typo?

https://www.gbmb.org/mbps-to-mbs

questions.question_text:
A network administrator has configured a new 100Mbs WAN circuit, but speed testing shows poor performance when downloading large files. The download initially reaches close to 100Mbps but begins to drop and show spikes in the downloads speeds over time. The administrator checks the router interface and sees the following:

Router01#show interface eth 1/1 -
GigabitEthernet 1/1 is up, line is up
Hardware is GigabitEthernet, address is 000A.00BB.CC11
Configured speed auto, actual 1Gbit, configured duplex fdx, actual fdx
Member of L2 VLAN 1, port is untagged, port state is forwarding
Which of the following is MOST likely to resolve the issue?
